hook.text: You can't touch it, hold it, or lock it in a safe. Yet intellectual property is worth trillions of dollars.

buildup.text: Intellectual property is a creation of the mind: inventions, designs, artistic works, names, and symbols.

discovery.text: IP law grants creators exclusive rights to control and profit from their creations for a limited time.

twist.text: Without IP protection, creators would have less incentive to innovateâ€”anyone could copy their work instantly.

climax.text: The four main types are patents, copyrights, trademarks, and trade secrets. Each protects different things.

punchline.text: Ideas aren't property. But the expression of ideas is.

quiz.question: What are the four main types of intellectual property?

topics.title: IP Clause in the US Constitution

hook.text: The Founders cared about innovation so much they wrote IP protection directly into the Constitution.

buildup.text: Article I, Section 8 empowers Congress to grant patents and copyrights to promote progress.

discovery.text: The clause says 'for limited times'â€”the Founders wanted IP rights to expire, not last forever.

twist.text: Congress has extended copyright terms repeatedly. Mickey Mouse's copyright expiration kept getting pushed back.

climax.text: Critics argue these extensions serve corporations, not creators, undermining the clause's original purpose.

punchline.text: The Constitution grants IP rights. It also meant them to end.

quiz.question: What does the Constitution say about IP protection duration?
options: It should be for limited times

hook.text: Shakespeare's plays are free to perform. Tolkien's books are not. The difference is the public domain.

buildup.text: The public domain is the body of creative works no longer protected by IP rights. Anyone can use them freely.

discovery.text: Works enter the public domain when their copyright expires, or if the creator dedicates them to it.

twist.text: In 2024, works from 1928 entered the public domainâ€”including early Mickey Mouse. Disney couldn't stop it.

climax.text: The public domain fuels new creation. West Side Story reimagined Romeo and Juliet because Shakespeare was free to use.

punchline.text: IP rights expire so the next generation can build on the last.

quiz.question: How do works enter the public domain?
options: When copyright expires or is voluntarily given up

hook.text: A company copies your product design exactly and sells it cheaper. That's infringementâ€”and you can sue.

buildup.text: IP infringement is unauthorized use of protected intellectual propertyâ€”using, copying, or selling without permission.

discovery.text: Each IP type has its own test: likelihood of confusion for trademarks, substantial similarity for copyrights.

twist.text: Infringement can be unintentional. You can violate a patent you never knew existed and still be liable.

climax.text: Remedies include injunctions, monetary damages, and sometimes the infringer's profits.

punchline.text: Using someone's IP without permission has a name: infringement.

quiz.question: Can you infringe a patent you didn't know about?

hook.text: A US patent means nothing in China. IP rights are territorialâ€”they stop at the border.

buildup.text: IP rights are granted by individual countries. There is no single worldwide patent or copyright.

discovery.text: Treaties like TRIPS and the Paris Convention set minimum standards that member countries must follow.

twist.text: Enforcement varies wildly. Some countries have strong IP courts; others barely enforce IP laws at all.

climax.text: Companies must register and enforce IP in every country where they do businessâ€”an expensive process.

punchline.text: IP is local. Business is global. That gap creates conflict.

quiz.question: What does TRIPS do for international IP?
options: Sets minimum IP standards for member countries

hook.text: Thomas Edison held 1,093 patents. Each one gave him a legal monopoly on an invention for years.

buildup.text: A patent grants the inventor exclusive rights to make, use, and sell an invention for a limited period.

discovery.text: Utility patents last 20 years from filing. Design patents last 15 years. Both require a formal application.

twist.text: In exchange, the inventor must publicly disclose how the invention works. Patents trade secrecy for protection.

climax.text: After expiration, anyone can use the invention. That's why generic drugs appear after pharmaceutical patents end.

punchline.text: A patent is a deal: share your invention, get temporary exclusivity.

quiz.question: How long does a US utility patent last?

hook.text: You can't patent a wheel. It already exists. Patentable inventions must be genuinely new.

buildup.text: Three requirements: the invention must be novel (new), useful (it works), and non-obvious (not an easy next step).

discovery.text: Novelty means no one has publicly disclosed the same invention beforeâ€”anywhere in the world.

twist.text: Non-obviousness is the trickiest test. A skilled person in the field shouldn't find the invention an obvious step.

climax.text: The patent office rejects most first applications. Inventors often narrow their claims through negotiation.

punchline.text: New, useful, and surprising. That's the patent trifecta.

quiz.question: What does 'non-obvious' mean in patent law?
options: The invention is hard to understand
A skilled person wouldn't find it an obvious next step

hook.text: A company that makes nothing sues a tech giant for billionsâ€”armed only with a vague patent it bought cheaply.

buildup.text: Patent trolls acquire patents not to innovate, but to sue companies for infringement and extract settlements.

discovery.text: They target small businesses that can't afford litigation. Settling for $50,000 is cheaper than fighting in court.

twist.text: Trolls cost the US economy billions annually. Many patents they wield are broad, vague, or arguably invalid.

climax.text: Reforms like inter partes review let companies challenge bad patents at the Patent Office before going to court.

punchline.text: Patents should reward inventors. Trolls reward lawyers.

quiz.question: What do patent trolls primarily do?
options: Buy patents to sue others for infringement

hook.text: A life-saving drug costs $10,000 a month. The patent expires and the generic version costs $50. Same drug.

buildup.text: Pharmaceutical companies patent new drugs, giving them exclusive rights to sell for 20 years from filing.

discovery.text: High prices during the patent period fund researchâ€”developing a new drug costs an average of $2.6 billion.

twist.text: Companies use 'evergreening'â€”filing new patents on minor changesâ€”to extend monopolies beyond the original term.

climax.text: The Hatch-Waxman Act balances innovation and access by streamlining generic drug approval after patents expire.

punchline.text: Patents fund research. Generics fund access. The tension is permanent.

quiz.question: What is 'evergreening' in pharmaceutical patents?
options: Filing new patents on minor changes to extend monopolies

hook.text: Apple sued Samsung over the iPhone's rounded rectangle designâ€”and won $539 million. That was a design patent.

buildup.text: Utility patents protect how an invention works. Design patents protect how it looks.

discovery.text: Design patents cover ornamental appearance only. The shape of a bottle, the pattern on a shoe, the look of an icon.

twist.text: Design patents last 15 years and are cheaper to get, but they're narrowerâ€”change the look slightly and you're clear.

climax.text: Many products are protected by both: a utility patent for function and a design patent for appearance.

punchline.text: Utility protects function. Design protects beauty. Both have teeth.

quiz.question: What does a design patent protect?
options: The ornamental appearance of an object
The brand name of a product

hook.text: The moment you write a poem, you own its copyright. No registration needed. Creation itself is enough.

buildup.text: Copyright protects original works of authorship: books, music, films, software, and art.

discovery.text: It gives the creator exclusive rights to reproduce, distribute, perform, and make derivative works.

twist.text: Copyright protects expression, not ideas. Two people can write different books about the same topic without conflict.

climax.text: For works created after 1978, copyright lasts the author's life plus 70 years. Corporate works get 95 years.

punchline.text: Create it and it's yours. That's copyright's promise.

quiz.question: What does copyright protect?

hook.text: A comedian parodies a hit song. The songwriter sues. The comedian winsâ€”it's fair use.

buildup.text: Fair use allows limited use of copyrighted material without permission for purposes like criticism and education.

discovery.text: Courts weigh four factors: purpose of use, nature of the work, amount used, and market impact.

twist.text: No bright-line rule exists. Fair use is decided case by case, making it the most unpredictable area of copyright law.

climax.text: Google's use of Java APIs in Android was ruled fair use by the Supreme Court after a decade-long legal battle.

punchline.text: Fair use is a defense, not a right. You argue it after you're sued.

quiz.question: How many factors do courts consider in fair use analysis?

hook.text: Napster let millions share music for free. The music industry lost billions. Copyright law had to catch up.

buildup.text: Digital technology makes copying instant and freeâ€”challenging the core of copyright enforcement.

discovery.text: The DMCA (1998) created takedown procedures and made circumventing copy protection illegal.

twist.text: Streaming solved piracy for music and film by making legal access easier than illegal downloads.

climax.text: But new challenges arise: AI-generated content, NFTs, and content on platforms complicate ownership questions.

punchline.text: Technology changes how we copy. Law struggles to keep pace.

quiz.question: What did the DMCA create?

topics.title: Work for Hire: Who Owns What You Create at Work

hook.text: You wrote a brilliant report for your employer. You created itâ€”but they own the copyright.

buildup.text: Under the work-for-hire doctrine, the employer owns the copyright when an employee creates work within their job scope.

discovery.text: For contractors, it's different. Work is only 'for hire' with a written agreement and specific categories.

twist.text: Many freelancers don't know this. Without a contract, they own what they createâ€”even if the client paid for it.

climax.text: The distinction between employee and contractor is crucial. Courts use multiple factors to decide.

punchline.text: Who owns the work depends on who you are, not just who paid.

quiz.question: Under work for hire, who owns an employee's creation?

hook.text: A photographer uploads a stunning image and says: use it free, just give me credit. That's Creative Commons.

buildup.text: Creative Commons licenses let creators share their work while keeping some rightsâ€”a middle ground.

discovery.text: Six standard licenses exist, ranging from very permissive (CC BY) to restrictive (CC BY-NC-ND).

twist.text: CC0 goes furthest: the creator waives all rights, placing the work in the public domain immediately.

climax.text: Wikipedia, open-source projects, and millions of images use CC licensesâ€”powering a global sharing economy.

punchline.text: All rights reserved isn't the only option. Some rights reserved works too.

quiz.question: What does a Creative Commons license do?
options: Lets creators share work while retaining some rights

hook.text: The Nike swoosh is worth billions. It's not the design that's valuableâ€”it's what customers associate with it.

buildup.text: A trademark is a word, symbol, or design that identifies the source of goods and distinguishes them from others.

discovery.text: Trademark rights come from use, not registration. Using a distinctive mark in commerce creates common law rights.

twist.text: USPTO registration provides stronger protection: nationwide priority, legal presumptions, and federal court access.

climax.text: Unlike patents and copyrights, trademarks can last foreverâ€”as long as they're used and defended.

punchline.text: A trademark doesn't protect the product. It protects the reputation.

quiz.question: How long can a trademark last?
options: Life of the owner plus 70 years

hook.text: 'Apple' for computers is strong. 'Apple' for an apple farm is weak. The same word gets different protection.

buildup.text: Trademarks are ranked by distinctiveness: fanciful, arbitrary, suggestive, descriptive, and generic.

discovery.text: Fanciful marks (Xerox) are the strongest. Generic terms (escalator, aspirin) get zero protection.

twist.text: Brands can become generic through overuse. Thermos, aspirin, and escalator all lost their trademark status.

climax.text: Google actively fights 'googling' becoming generic. If it does, they could lose their trademark.

punchline.text: Too much success can kill a trademark. Popularity is a double-edged sword.

quiz.question: What happens when a trademark becomes generic?

hook.text: A store called 'Starbuds Coffee' opens down the street from Starbucks. Is that infringement?

buildup.text: Trademark infringement occurs when someone uses a similar mark in a way that creates consumer confusion.

discovery.text: Courts analyze several factors: similarity of marks, proximity of goods, and evidence of actual confusion.

twist.text: You can use someone's trademark to discuss their product. Comparative advertising is legal if truthful.

climax.text: Famous marks get extra protection against 'dilution'â€”even without confusion, weakening a famous brand is actionable.

punchline.text: If customers might be confused, the trademark owner has a case.

quiz.question: What is the key test for trademark infringement?
options: Whether there's likelihood of consumer confusion
Whether both businesses are in the same city

hook.text: Someone registered your company's name as a domain before you didâ€”and wants $100,000 to sell it back.

buildup.text: Cybersquatting is registering domain names matching trademarks with the intent to profit from them.

discovery.text: The Anticybersquatting Consumer Protection Act (ACPA) lets trademark owners recover domains registered in bad faith.

twist.text: Not all matching domains are cybersquatting. If someone legitimately has the name, first-come-first-served applies.

climax.text: ICANN's dispute resolution process (UDRP) offers a faster, cheaper alternative to court litigation.

punchline.text: A domain is digital real estate. Trademark law decides who owns the address.

quiz.question: What law addresses cybersquatting in the US?

topics.title: Trade Dress: Protecting Look and Feel

hook.text: The Coca-Cola bottle shape is protectedâ€”not as a patent or copyright, but as trade dress.

buildup.text: Trade dress protects the overall visual impression of a product: packaging, design, color, and layout.

discovery.text: It must be distinctive and non-functional. You can't trademark a shape that's necessary for the product to work.

twist.text: Apple's retail stores have trade dress protectionâ€”the glass facade and minimalist layout are legally distinctive.

climax.text: Trade dress claims are hard to win. Proving consumers associate a look with a specific brand requires strong evidence.

punchline.text: Sometimes the package is the brand. Trade dress protects that.

quiz.question: What does trade dress protect?
options: The overall visual impression of a product or packaging

topics.title: What Qualifies as a Trade Secret?

hook.text: The Coca-Cola formula has been secret for over 130 years. No patent, no registrationâ€”just secrecy.

buildup.text: A trade secret is information that derives economic value from not being generally known and is kept secret.

discovery.text: It can be a formula, process, customer list, algorithm, or any business info that gives a competitive edge.

twist.text: Unlike patents, trade secrets last foreverâ€”but only as long as secrecy is maintained. One leak and it's gone.

climax.text: The owner must take reasonable steps to protect the secret: NDAs, restricted access, and security measures.

punchline.text: A trade secret's power is its secrecy. Reveal it and the protection vanishes.

quiz.question: How long does trade secret protection last?
options: Life of the creator plus 70 years
As long as the secret is maintained

topics.title: Trade Secret vs. Patent: The Strategic Choice

hook.text: Coca-Cola chose secrecy. Pharmaceutical companies choose patents. Both protect valuable inventions differently.

buildup.text: Patents require disclosure but give strong, enforceable rights. Trade secrets need no disclosure but are fragile.

discovery.text: If your invention can be reverse-engineered, a patent is smarter. If it can't, a trade secret may last longer.

twist.text: You can't have both. Filing a patent publishes the invention, destroying any trade secret protection.

climax.text: Google's search algorithm is a trade secret. Its patents cover specific technical methods, not the whole system.

punchline.text: Patent means share and protect. Trade secret means hide and hope.

quiz.question: When is a trade secret better than a patent?
options: When the invention can't be reverse-engineered

hook.text: Before seeing the startup's business plan, the investor signs an NDA. Now sharing that info could mean a lawsuit.

buildup.text: A non-disclosure agreement (NDA) is a contract that binds someone to keep shared information confidential.

discovery.text: NDAs define what's confidential, how long the obligation lasts, and what happens if someone breaches.

twist.text: NDAs are only as strong as your willingness to enforce them. A breach with no lawsuit sets a dangerous precedent.

climax.text: Some NDAs are mutualâ€”both sides share secrets. Others are one-way, protecting only one party's information.

punchline.text: An NDA turns a handshake promise into a legal obligation.

quiz.question: What is the primary purpose of an NDA?

hook.text: An engineer at a US company stole chip designs for a Chinese competitor. It wasn't just theftâ€”it was a federal crime.

buildup.text: The Economic Espionage Act (1996) makes theft of trade secrets a federal crime, with harsh penalties.

discovery.text: It covers two offenses: economic espionage (for a foreign government) and commercial trade secret theft.

twist.text: Penalties reach $5 million in fines and 15 years in prison for espionage benefiting a foreign state.

climax.text: The Defend Trade Secrets Act (2016) added a federal civil cause of action, letting companies sue directly.

punchline.text: Stealing ideas isn't just unethical. It's criminal.

quiz.question: What does the Economic Espionage Act criminalize?

hook.text: A top engineer leaves for a competitor. She knows the secret formula. Can her old employer stop her?

buildup.text: Employees often carry trade secrets in their heads. When they leave, the risk of disclosure spikes.

discovery.text: Companies use NDAs, non-competes, and exit interviews to protect secrets during employee transitions.

twist.text: General knowledge and skills belong to the employee. Only specific proprietary information is protectable.

climax.text: The inevitable disclosure doctrine lets courts block employees from roles where they'd inevitably use trade secrets.

punchline.text: You can leave your job. You can't take the secrets with you.

quiz.question: What does the inevitable disclosure doctrine allow?
options: Courts to block roles where trade secrets would inevitably be used

hook.text: An AI painted a portrait that sold for $432,500. Who owns the copyrightâ€”the AI, the programmer, or nobody?

buildup.text: The US Copyright Office says only human-authored works qualify for copyright. AI-generated works don't.

discovery.text: This creates a gap: billions of AI-generated images, texts, and music have no clear copyright owner.

twist.text: If a human makes creative choices guiding the AI, those choices may create enough authorship for copyright.

climax.text: Courts worldwide are grappling with this. China has granted AI-related copyrights; the US has not.

punchline.text: AI can create. The law hasn't decided if it can own.

quiz.question: Can AI-generated works be copyrighted in the US currently?
options: Yes, the programmer always owns it

hook.text: Linux powers most of the internetâ€”and anyone can use, modify, and share it. Free software isn't lawless; it's licensed.

buildup.text: Open source licenses grant broad permissions to use and modify software while imposing certain conditions.

discovery.text: Permissive licenses (MIT, Apache) allow almost anything. Copyleft licenses (GPL) require sharing modifications.

twist.text: Violating GPL means your own code may need to be open-sourced. Companies have been caught off guard by this.

climax.text: Open source created a multi-trillion-dollar ecosystem. IP law made it possible through carefully designed licenses.

punchline.text: Open source uses copyright law to guarantee freedom, not restrict it.

quiz.question: What does a copyleft license (like GPL) require?
options: Sharing modifications under the same license

hook.text: Apple, Samsung, Google, and Microsoft spent more on patent lawsuits than on research in some years.

buildup.text: The smartphone patent wars of the 2010s saw tech giants suing each other over thousands of overlapping patents.

discovery.text: Companies built massive patent portfolios as both swords (to attack competitors) and shields (for counter-suits).

twist.text: Many fought to a standstill. Cross-licensing agreements ended the warsâ€”each side agreed to use the other's patents.

climax.text: The wars showed that in tech, patents can slow innovation as much as protect it.

punchline.text: When everyone sues everyone, nobody innovates.

quiz.question: How did most smartphone patent wars end?

hook.text: A $50 'Rolex' on a street corner is obviously fake. But counterfeiting costs the global economy $500 billion yearly.

buildup.text: Counterfeiting is producing and selling goods under someone else's trademark without authorization.

discovery.text: It goes far beyond luxury goods: fake medicines, electronics, and car parts pose real safety risks.

twist.text: Online marketplaces made counterfeiting easier to do and harder to police. Sellers disappear and reappear endlessly.

climax.text: Customs agencies worldwide seize counterfeit goods at borders, but the volume far exceeds enforcement capacity.

punchline.text: Counterfeiting steals more than brands. It steals safety and trust.

quiz.question: What danger does counterfeiting pose beyond brand harm?
options: Safety risks from fake medicines and parts

hook.text: A company uses a celebrity's face to sell products without permission. The celebrity suesâ€”and wins.

buildup.text: The right of publicity protects a person's name, image, and likeness from unauthorized commercial use.

discovery.text: It's a state-level right in the US. Some states offer strong protection; others have minimal laws.

twist.text: AI deepfakes raised new questions. Can someone create a fake video of you selling a product you never endorsed?

climax.text: Several states are passing laws specifically targeting AI-generated likenesses to fill this legal gap.

punchline.text: Your face is yours. No one should profit from it without asking.

quiz.question: What does the right of publicity protect?
options: A person's name, image, and likeness from commercial misuse
The right to run for office
